content:
I thought I would try to golf down Diaconescu's theorem, as a proof term, for fun.

Rules:

  • Must work in the same context as the original proof of Diaconescu's theorem. So, no using tauto or similar.
  • Any mixture of term mode / tactic mode is fine.
  • Goal is to minimize character count, from the := in theorem em (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p := until the last character of the proof.
  • Any unicode characters / special notation is fine, as long as it's already defined by that point in Init.
  • Standard axioms (propext, Quot.sound, and of course Classical.choice) are allowed, but not sorryAx.

I got a solution in 254 characters, and I'd love to know if someone can beat it! :)

Spoilered proof term:

Solution (254 chars)

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=open Or in((choose_spec (⟨True,inr rfl⟩:Exists$ Or _∘_)).rec
inl λt↦(choose_spec (⟨False,inr rfl⟩:Exists$ Or _∘_)).rec inl λf↦inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false:_∨_≠_).rec
inl$ inr∘mt λh↦show∀{u v},_=choose v from have:=funext λ_↦propext ⟨λ_↦inl h,λ_↦inl h⟩
by congr

This game was partially inspired by the idea that, "come on, the excluded middle can't require _that_ nontrivial of a proof...". My solution is pretty much entirely just minimizing the existing proof in Init. If someone has a cleaner basic idea to the proof, that could definitely lead to something much shorter I'm sure

I found some more savings:

Solution (205 chars)

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=open Or
in((choose_spec (⟨True,inr rfl⟩:Exists$ _∘_)).rec inl
λt↦(choose_spec (⟨False,inr rfl⟩:Exists$ Or _∘_)).rec inl
λf↦inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false:_∨_≠_).rec inl$
inr∘mt λh↦by congr;exact funext$ by simp[h]
Ooh, nice.

Got one fewer character:

Solution (204 chars)

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=((choose_spec (⟨True,Or.inr rfl⟩:Exists$ _∘_)).rec .inl
λt↦(choose_spec (⟨False,.inr rfl⟩:Exists$ Or _∘_)).rec .inl
λf↦.inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false:_∨_≠_).rec .inl$
.inr∘mt λh↦by congr;exact funext$ by simp[h]
You can save one more characteer by replacing the last line by .inr∘mt (by congr;exact funext$ by simp[·]).
I wouldn't have thought of that use of ·!
That feels illegal! :o

Damiano Testa said:

You can save one more characteer by replacing the last line by .inr∘mt (by congr;exact funext$ by simp[·]).

You can save 4 more characters by using .inr∘mt (by congr;apply funext;simp[·])

193 characters

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by congr;apply funext;simp[·]))$
(choose_spec (⟨True,Or.inr rfl⟩:Exists$ _∘_)).rec .inl
λt↦(choose_spec (⟨False,Or.inr rfl⟩:Exists$ _∘_)).rec .inl
λf↦.inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false

I'm not sure if this is valid:

185 characters?

notation"v"a=>choose_spec (a:Exists$ _∘_)
theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by congr;apply funext;simp[·]))$
(v⟨True,Or.inr rfl⟩).rec .inl
λt↦(v⟨False,Or.inr rfl⟩).rec .inl
λf↦.inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false

181?

notation a"v"b=>Or.rec Or.inl b (choose_spec (a:Exists$ _∘_))
theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by congr;apply funext;simp[·]))$
⟨True,Or.inr rfl⟩vλt↦⟨False,Or.inr rfl⟩vλf↦.inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false

179

notation a"/"b=>Or.rec Or.inl b$ choose_spec (Exists.intro a$ Or.inr rfl:Exists$ _∘_)
theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by congr;apply funext;simp[·]))$
True/λt↦False/λf↦.inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false

Without notation, 179 characters

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by congr;apply funext;simp[·]))$
(choose_spec (⟨True,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)).rec .inl
λt↦(choose_spec (⟨False,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)).rec .inl
λf↦.inr$ f▸t▸true_ne_false
Haha, I like the /λ one, at least in part because of how wacky the result looks. :) I'd count that!

I believe this has 151

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
have x:=λy:Prop↦(choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_))
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x True).rec .inl
λt↦x False|>.rec .inl (.inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)

You can drop 7 more in that first line:

144 characters

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
have x:=λy↦choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x True).rec .inl
λt↦x False|>.rec .inl (.inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)

Edit: make that 8 more

143 characters

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x:=λy↦choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x True).rec .inl
λt↦x False|>.rec .inl (.inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)
Almost short enough for an old-school tweet at this point! (I know they've since raised it to 280 chars)

142 characters

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=(⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_).choose_spec
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x True).rec .inl
λt↦x False|>.rec .inl (.inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)

As we have been implicitly adding open Exists all along, if we implicitly add open Exists Or, then we can get rid of a lot of .!

136 discounting the opens

open Exists Or

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=(⟨y,inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_).choose_spec
.rec inl (inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x True).rec inl
λt↦x False|>.rec inl (inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)

We have been adding open Exists?

prelude
import Init.PropLemmas

universe u v

/-! # Classical reasoning support -/

namespace Classical

noncomputable def indefiniteDescription {α : Sort u} (p : α → Prop) (h : ∃ x, p x) : {x // p x} :=
  choice <| let ⟨x, px⟩ := h; ⟨⟨x, px⟩⟩

/--
Given that there exists an element satisfying `p`, returns one such element.

This is a straightforward consequence of, and equivalent to, `Classical.choice`.

See also `choose_spec`, which asserts that the returned value has property `p`.
-/
noncomputable def choose {α : Sort u} {p : α → Prop} (h : ∃ x, p x) : α :=
  (indefiniteDescription p h).val

theorem choose_spec {α : Sort u} {p : α → Prop} (h : ∃ x, p x) : p (choose h) :=
  (indefiniteDescription p h).property

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x True).rec .inl
λt↦x False|>.rec .inl (.inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)

works
Note that Exists.choose_spec is only defined after em
Oh, I was opening it in the online server and it doesn't work without open Exists...

Damiano Testa said:

As we have been implicitly adding open Exists all along,

Mine works without this :)
I think you should only need open Classical
Eric, I just noticed that yours expliots dot-notation, not implicit dot! Very nice!
So, the savings that come from removing . do not compensate for adding open Or... :sad:

Alex Meiburg said:

I think you should only need open Classical

em is proved in namespace Classical, so I think this is ok
theorem Classical.en has the effect of opening the namespace for you

Eric Wieser said:

142 characters

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=(⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_).choose_spec
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x True).rec .inl
λt↦x False|>.rec .inl (.inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)


As written I think this is referring to Exists.choose_spec, you can move the choose spec to the start of that and use a space without losing a character

So...

133?

theorem Or.en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=(⟨y,inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_).choose_spec
rec inl (inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|x True|>rec inl
λt↦x False|>rec inl (inr$ ·▸t▸true_ne_false)

from what I understand the requirement is for it to work in the same context as the original proof, so using theorem Or.en doesn't work - you have to end Classical first, and that still wouldn't work because Exists.choose_spec is defined after em is proved
And here I was thinking that we were goofing around, rather than seriously applying some rules... :smile:

True and False are long constants and (just purely asthetically) extra types that don't seem fundamentally relevant to the problem. The only thing really needed is that they are two props that are definitely not equal. So I have to believe there should be a way to do it where you choose p ∨ x = p and p ∨ x = ¬p, instead of True and False; simp can already prove that Not (p = Not p). But I having trouble getting it to work.

Alex Meiburg said:

True and False are long constants and (just purely asthetically) extra types that don't seem fundamentally relevant to the problem. The only thing really needed is that they are two props that are definitely not equal. So I have to believe there should be a way to do it where you choose p ∨ x = p and p ∨ x = ¬p, instead of True and False; simp can already prove that Not (p = Not p). But I having trouble getting it to work.

They don't even have to be props — Nat and Bool could work, if you can get a short proof of Nat≠Bool

Good catch. 140 characters, a tweet! Edit: 137, stray parens+spaces

137 chars (no namespace hacks :) )

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x 0).rec .inl
λt↦x 1|>.rec .inl (.inr$ ·▸t▸Nat.one_ne_zero)

132

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)
.rec .inl (.inr∘mt (by simp[·]))<|(x 0).rec .inl
λt↦x 1|>.imp_right (·▸t▸Nat.one_ne_zero)

128

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)
.imp_right (mt (by simp[·]))<|(x 0).rec .inl
λt↦x 1|>.imp_right (·▸t▸Nat.one_ne_zero)

122

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
let x y:=choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃q,p∨_)
.imp id (mt (by simp[·]))<|(x 0).rec .inl
λt↦x 1|>.imp id (·▸t▸Nat.one_ne_zero)
are you counting characters or bytes? Code golf.SE does bytes and that makes most of the unicode not really worth it
We're counting chars. I think even counting bytes, though, most of the unicode here will still be worth it
the mapsto probably not, the lambda yes, certainly the exists
For \t I don't think there is an alternative
This is 138 bytes after replacing the ↦
The cdot can be simply a period, for -2 bytes

121

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
(λx↦.imp id (mt (by simp[·]))<|(x 0).rec .inl
λt↦x 1|>.imp id (·▸t▸Nat.one_ne_zero))
λy↦choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃_,p∨_)
this is probably not a net benefit by bytes

117

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
(λx↦.imp id (mt (by simp[·]))<|(x 0).rec .inl
λt↦x 1|>.imp id (·▸t▸(nofun:1≠0)))
λy↦choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃_,p∨_)
Abstracting the let: wow!
too bad the notation λ. for nofun was dropped

115

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
(λx↦.imp id (mt (by simp[·]))<|(x 0).rec .inl$
(x 1).imp id∘(·▸·▸(nofun:1≠0)))
λy↦choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃_,p∨_)

112

theorem en (p : Prop) : p ∨ ¬p :=
(λx↦.imp id (by simp[·,·])<|(x 0).rec .inl$
(x 1).imp id∘(·▸·▸(nofun:1≠0)))
λy↦choose_spec (⟨y,.inr rfl⟩:∃_,p∨_)

I am still hoping that at some point we will have a "library golf" measurement tool. I would love to have an easy way to measure the size of the environment needed to implement a given spec (Classical.em or Real or whatever) for various implementations of that spec.

I guess Daniel is the winner! :)
So now we merge this updated proof in right? :P
